climbs.name: Windy Crack
climbs.fa: Stewart Green, Cliff Powers, and Keo Boulton, 2011

content.description: A fun moderate climb, with a cool top out on canyon point butte.
content.protection: The first pitch is protected by one bolt on a pocketed face, and the crack takes hand sized protection. there is fixed anchors on the first pitch and at the top of the third, but only one drilled in piton for the intermediate belay station at the start of pitch two. (piton has been removed)
content.location:
P1:From the Right facing crack climb up the short chimney to gain the top of the ledge and there will be a single bolt on the main butte. follow the cupped pockets to the first belay station. P2:Continue from belay station and head North on ridge line till you come to the base of two cracks.

P3:build a natural belay station and climb the Right crack to another set of anchors just above the crack to the left. From here continue up on easy fourth class to the summit.

content.description: Although it's on the shorter side, I'm gonna toss it out there that this may be one of the finest finger cracks in the Moab area. I was amazed to find it unclimbed. I attempted it once, on-sight from the ground, and was able to pull it off my 2nd try a few weeks later, also ground-up. For strong finger crack climbers it would certainly make a reasonable on-sight. I made a plaque, but left off the "+" just in case I was super-psyched and it turns out that others think it's easier.
content.protection: I used, in order, .75, #4 in an obvious box, 000c3, 00c3, 0c3, green Alien, .3, 3 or 4 .4s in a row, another .3, and a red Alien. There is no anchor. There is an easy scramble to the top, from the left, which can be used to pre-set an anchor if you like. I lowered a loop once on top and hauled up an old #4, new #5, a 1 and a 2. Please do not add bolts for an anchor, and do not top-rope this route with the rope running over the edge. The rock is soft and won't tolerate much wear.
content.location: On the West Face, only about 100 yards away from the Tombstone. Look for the obvious splitter in the scoop.
